data.meaning_mnemonic: This radical looks just like a stick figure—more specifically, a really <radical>big</radical> guy with his arms stretched out nice and big. When you see this radical, just think big, because this guy is really BIG!
The <radical>South</radical> <radical>Dog</radical> gives you an <kanji>offer</kanji>. None of the other dogs in the North, East, or West offered you anything.
data.meaning_hint: It is well known that dogs in the South are famous for their kindness and hospitality. It's customary to always offer something when a guest arrives.
data.reading_mnemonic: The South Dog <kanji>offer</kanji>s you the services of <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai as you traverse his lands.
data.reading_hint: Ken offers to carry you, too. Imagine him offering this. You can choose whether or not to accept in your mind.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is also the reading you learned. How nice! But if you don't remember it, what a <vocabulary>shame</vocabulary>. What an <vocabulary>embarrassment</vocabulary> this must be for you.

context_sentences.en: He thinks I embarrassed him in front of everybody.
context_sentences.ja: あいつ、俺にみんなの前で恥をかかされたって思ってるみたいでさ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Bear</kanji> <kanji>origin</kanji> <kanji>prefecture</kanji> is <vocabulary>Kumamoto Prefecture</vocabulary>. Probably best to learn this meaning via the reading. Also, you should look up Kumamon of Kumamoto-ken.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is <ja>熊</ja>'s reading, the alternate "origin" <ja>本</ja> reading, and the reading for <ja>県</ja>.

context_sentences.en: The night bus service was temporarily suspended because of an accident in Kumamoto prefecture.
context_sentences.ja: 夜行バスは、熊本県で発生した事故のため一時不通になった。

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you're <kanji>mud</kanji> <kanji>drunk</kanji>, you're so drunk you're rolling around on the ground. You are <vocabulary>dead drunk</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: I was completely drunk and lost my sense of direction.
context_sentences.ja: 完璧に泥酔していて、方向感覚を失っていました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that the kanji means <kanji>related</kanji>. As a verb, this often means <vocabulary>to be involved</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be related</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>to be connected</vocabulary>. Basically, things that have to do with being related to something else.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  

Ever heard of the "<reading>Kaw Kaw</reading> (<ja>かか</ja>) Crow Gang"? They are bad news, always eating from garbage and squawking "kaw kaw" ... You don't want <vocabulary>to be involved</vocabulary> with them.

context_sentences.en: This is a huge problem related to people's everyday lives.
context_sentences.ja: これは人々の生活に関わる大問題だ。

context_sentences.en: I have been involved in many projects, but this one is the most exciting.
context_sentences.ja: 今まで色々なプロジェクトに関わってきましたが、今回のプロジェクトが一番ワクワクします。

context_sentences.en: Allergies are not to be taken lightly. They can be life-threatening!
context_sentences.ja: アレルギーは軽く見たらダメだよ。命に関わることもあるんだから！

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Something that is <kanji>tall</kanji> in <kanji>degrees</kanji> can either refer to its <vocabulary>altitude</vocabulary>, or to the fact that it's quite <vocabulary>high-level</vocabulary>. 

Note that this can refer to any altitude, even lower ones. But when used to refer to, for example, skills or a technique, it always talks about a high level or degree.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: This UFO is now at an altitude of 33,000 feet.
context_sentences.ja: このUFOは、今、高度3万3000フィートのところにいる。

context_sentences.en: Michael used advanced techniques to complete one difficult game after another.
context_sentences.ja: マイケルは、高度なテクニックを使って、むずかしいゲームを次々クリアした。

context_sentences.en: If the altitude is too high, the air becomes too thin and it'll cause the engine to flame out.
context_sentences.ja: 高度を上げすぎると空気がうすくなって、エンジンがフレームアウトしちゃうんだよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>construct</kanji> and the verb version is <vocabulary>to build something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to construct something</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you know, the best way <vocabulary>to build something</vocabulary> is with <reading>kiss</reading>es (<ja>きず</ja>). Kisses build relationships, happy families, and better societies. So get building with those kisses of yours.

context_sentences.en: Greetings are essential for building good relationships.
context_sentences.ja: 良好な人間関係を築くのに、あいさつは欠かせません。

context_sentences.en: My dream is to build a happy family with you.
context_sentences.ja: 私の夢は、あなたと幸せな家庭を築くことです。

context_sentences.en: Today, let's all think about what we can do to build a better society.
context_sentences.ja: 今日はみんなで、より良い社会を築くためには何をすればいいかを考えましょう。

meanings.meaning: Something Heard For The First Time

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: Hearing Something For The First Time

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>first</kanji> time something reaches your <kanji>ear</kanji>, it's <vocabulary>something heard for the first time</vocabulary>. If it's never entered your ear before, it's <vocabulary>news</vocabulary> to you!
data.reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses kun'yomi instead of on'yomi readings. You already know how to read <ja>耳</ja>, but you haven't learned the kun'yomi for <ja>初</ja> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

Whatever it is, this <vocabulary>something heard for the first time</vocabulary>, be sure to hold onto your <reading>hats</reading> (<ja>はつ</ja>)! It's going to be something big, and I'm pretty sure it's going to be <vocabulary>news</vocabulary> to me, too.

context_sentences.en: Huh, that's the first I've heard of it.
context_sentences.ja: ええっ、それは初耳です。

context_sentences.en: Seriously? That's all news to me!
context_sentences.ja: マジ？そんな話、初耳だぞ！？

context_sentences.en: This term may be new to many of you.
context_sentences.ja: この言葉は、初耳の人も多いかもしれませんね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is the same <ja>岡山</ja> that you learned with <ja>岡山県</ja>. So what's Okayama <kanji>castle</kanji>? Yep, <vocabulary>Okayama Castle</vocabulary>!
data.reading_mnemonic:
When <ja>城</ja> is added to a place name like this, it takes the on'yomi. You haven't learned this yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The lord of <vocabulary>Okayama Castle</vocabulary> is none other than <reading>Jourm</reading> (<ja>じょう</ja>). How a farmhand managed to become the lord of a Japanese castle is beyond even us, but it's Lord Jourm to you now.

context_sentences.en: The night illumination of Okayama Castle was so beautiful!
context_sentences.ja: 岡山城のライトアップ、めっちゃきれいだったよ！

context_sentences.en: On Sunday, I visited the renovated Okayama Castle.
context_sentences.ja: 日曜日、リニューアルした岡山城に行ってきました。

context_sentences.en: If the weather is good, Okayama Castle will be clearly visible from here.
context_sentences.ja: 天気が良ければ、ここからも岡山城がはっきり見えるんですよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you're <kanji>hold</kanji>ing food and <kanji>return</kanji>ing home with it, you're likely getting <vocabulary>takeout</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: You've already learned how to read both <ja>持つ</ja> and <ja>帰る</ja>, so you should be able to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: I'd like this one to go, please.
context_sentences.ja: これはお持ち帰りでお願いします。

context_sentences.en: What shall we do, eat at a restaurant? Get takeout?
context_sentences.ja: どうする、お店で食べる？お持ち帰りにする？

context_sentences.en: Here's the take-out order for customer number two!
context_sentences.ja: こちら、二番さんのお持ち帰りのオーダーのお品になります！

data.meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji means <kanji>male</kanji> and this also means <vocabulary>male</vocabulary>. It's used for animals, plants, and the like.

Note that this is often written in katakana, as in <ja>オス</ja>.
data.reading_mnemonic: <vocabulary>Male</vocabulary> animals can be kind of pushy, always trying <reading>to push</reading> (<ja>押す</ja>) other animals around, trying to be the alpha and all.

context_sentences.en: Is it true that many male cats are left-handed?
context_sentences.ja: 猫の雄に左利きが多いって本当ですか？

context_sentences.en: Apparently all the puppies that were born were male!
context_sentences.ja: 生まれた子犬、みんな雄だったみたい！

context_sentences.en: The male golden-backed squirrel courts by making a frog-like croaking sound.
context_sentences.ja: タイワンリスの雄は、カエルのような鳴き声を出して求愛します。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
When a <kanji>warm</kanji> temper is applied extra <kanji>thick</kanji>, it leads to a person having a <vocabulary>mild-mannered</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>gentle</vocabulary> personality.

Note that this is a more formal term, so you'll usually encounter it in writing.
data.reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You already know the on'yomi for <ja>温</ja>, but not for <ja>厚</ja>, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

The most <vocabulary>mild-mannered</vocabulary> Tofugu staff has to be <reading>on</reading>ion <reading><ja>こう</reading>いち</ja>. It's an onion that jumps in for こういち whenever he's not at the office. He's the most <vocabulary>gentle</vocabulary> soul you could imagine, never yelling at anyone. The ideal boss, really.

context_sentences.en: My husband does everything at his own pace and has gentle nature.
context_sentences.ja: 夫はマイペースで、温厚な性格です。

context_sentences.en: That person is usually mild-mannered, but when he gets angry, he's scary.
context_sentences.ja: あの人、普段は温厚だけど、怒らせると怖いよ。

context_sentences.en: If anything, I think I am on the mild-mannered side.
context_sentences.ja: どちらかといえば、オレは温厚なほうだと思う。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
What <kanji>kind</kanji>s of <vocabulary>seed</vocabulary>s are you going to sow? Think about all the different the kinds of seeds, and the kinds of plants they'll grow into.

This can also mean <vocabulary>source</vocabulary>, as in a source of worry or joy, or even of a good story.
data.reading_mnemonic: Choose your <vocabulary>seed</vocabulary>s carefully, because you love to have a <reading>tan eh?</reading> (<ja>たね</ja>). You love tanning, so you don't want to plant anything that will grow tall and create shade. Choose those seed types carefully, and don't forget about your tan, eh?

context_sentences.en: Over there, I received sunflower seeds.
context_sentences.ja: あそこで、ヒマワリの種をもらいました。

context_sentences.en: When are you going to sow those seeds?
context_sentences.ja: その種、いつまくの？

context_sentences.en: Thanks, you've given me a good story to tell.
context_sentences.ja: ありがとう、いい話の種ができたよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
If you <kanji>untie</kanji> something that's <kanji>frozen</kanji>, you're <vocabulary>thawing</vocabulary> it. The best way to go about <vocabulary>defrosting</vocabulary> anything is always to untie it first.

In the context of computer files, this word can also mean <vocabulary>unzipping</vocabulary>. We unzip files in English, but in Japanese we thaw them!
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi for both kanji, so you should be able to read this one on your own.

context_sentences.en: I wonder how long it will take to thaw this turkey.
context_sentences.ja: このターキー、解凍するのにどのくらい時間かかるかな？

context_sentences.en: The defrosting method should be written on the packaging.
context_sentences.ja: パッケージに解凍方法が書いてあるはずだよ。

context_sentences.en: To open this file, you will need a file extractor.
context_sentences.ja: このファイルを開くには、解凍ソフトが必要です。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>push</kanji>, and this verb means things like <vocabulary>to hold something down</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to grasp something</vocabulary>. This verb is pretty versatile, and you can use it if you're holding down a piece of paper, holding a cloth to a wound, or grasping a concept.
data.reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, so hopefully you can read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: The alien held down the man's head forcefully with his left hand.
context_sentences.ja: 宇宙人は左手でガッと男の頭を押さえた。

context_sentences.en: These words are important, so make sure to master them!
context_sentences.ja: この単語は大事なので、しっかり押さえておきましょう！

context_sentences.en: What's wrong? You're holding your stomach.
context_sentences.ja: どうしたの、お腹押さえて。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>exit</kanji> the building and <kanji>stretch</kanji> in preparation for your <vocabulary>business trip</vocabulary>. This is the routine you always follow for your business trips: exit, and stretch.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just be careful about <ja>しゅつ</ja> becoming <ja>しゅっ</ja> here!

context_sentences.en: I just arrived at the hotel where I will be staying during the business trip.
context_sentences.ja: 今、出張先のホテルに着いたところだよ。

context_sentences.en: My father is on an overseas business trip.
context_sentences.ja: 父は海外出張中なんです。

context_sentences.en: Speaking of Nagoya, I've been there on a business trip.
context_sentences.ja: 名古屋なら、出張で行ったことがあるよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Here we have <kanji>nothing</kanji>, followed by the verb <ja>なる</ja>. A verb that means "become nothing"? That'll be <vocabulary>to be gone</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to run out</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be lost</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to disappear</vocabulary>.

This can be translated in various ways depending on the situation, but just remember that it always refers to something changing from being there, to not being there.
data.reading_mnemonic: This uses the kun'yomi reading, which you learned with <ja>無し</ja>, so you should be good to go.

context_sentences.en: Oh, our toilet paper is almost gone.
context_sentences.ja: あ、トイレットペーパー、もうすぐ無くなるよ。

context_sentences.en: I've run out of things to do and I'm bored.
context_sentences.ja: することが無くなっちゃって、ヒマなんだよね。

context_sentences.en: In a credit card society, the need to carry cash has almost disappeared.
context_sentences.ja: カード社会では、現金を持つ必要がほぼ無くなった。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
The time of <kanji>young</kanji> <kanji>spring</kanji> for humans is really just their <vocabulary>youth</vocabulary>. Just like plants in spring, your <vocabulary>adolescence</vocabulary> is when you start growing to your full potential! You might even say it's <vocabulary>the springtime of one's life</vocabulary>.

This is generally refers to the period when you’re an energetic teenager and young adult. It can have connotations of exhilarating experiences and bittersweet feelings, as well as nostalgic memories.
data.reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned the on'yomi for <ja>春</ja> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Don't let your <vocabulary>youth</vocabulary> go to waste, because it will be over <reading>soon</reading> (<ja>しゅん</ja>)!

context_sentences.en: This is a photo that captures the springtime of my life.
context_sentences.ja: これは青春時代の思い出の写真です。

context_sentences.en: It's just like a page out of our youth!
context_sentences.ja: まさに青春の１ページって感じだね！

context_sentences.en: Emi, you're fully relishing your youth!
context_sentences.ja: エミ、めっちゃ青春してるじゃん！

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Add a <ja>に</ja> to <kanji>every</kanji> and you get <vocabulary>for every</vocabulary>. This means something happens <vocabulary>at intervals of</vocabulary> a certain time frame or milestone, like <vocabulary>once every</vocabulary> year, month, day, etc.!

Note that this is very frequently written in hiragana, but you'll encounter the kanji version as well, especially when it follows a number.
data.reading_mnemonic:
This uses the kun'yomi reading of <ja>毎</ja>, which you haven't learned yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>For every</vocabulary> kanji you burn, you <reading>go to</reading> (<ja>ごと</ja>) Tokyo Disneyland as a reward. It's a bit of an expensive habit, but I think you deserve it.

context_sentences.en: I'll add five more Amazon gift cards to the giveaway for every 100 retweets I get!
context_sentences.ja: 100RT毎にプレゼントのアマギフを5枚追加するよ！

context_sentences.en: Right now I'm giving him formula roughly every three hours.
context_sentences.ja: 今は大体三時間毎にミルクをあげてる。

context_sentences.en: We have our car inspected once every year.
context_sentences.ja: うちの車は、一年毎に点検に出しています。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Being <kanji>fierce</kanji> and <kanji>angry</kanji> means you're filled with <vocabulary>rage</vocabulary>. If you were looking for a word to describe all your <vocabulary>indignation</vocabulary>, then this is it.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: When my mother saw this, she was absolutely furious.
context_sentences.ja: それを見た母は、大激怒でした。

context_sentences.en: The film altered the original story so much that it drew the rage of fans.
context_sentences.ja: この映画は、原作を改変しすぎてファンの激怒を買いました。

context_sentences.en: Putting one's shoes on a bench may be fine in other countries, but in Japan it would cause indignation.
context_sentences.ja: 土足でベンチに上がるの、海外ならいいかもしれないけど、日本では激怒ものだよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
It's the <kanji>origin</kanji> of all <kanji>origin</kanji>s, so it's the way it was <vocabulary>originally</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>from the beginning</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>by nature</vocabulary>. You get the idea.

Note that this is frequently written in just hiragana, but you'll encounter the kanji version too!
data.reading_mnemonic: This is just the kun'yomi reading you learned with <ja>元</ja>, but twice, so you should be good to go!

context_sentences.en: This area was originally pink.
context_sentences.ja: ここは元々はピンクだったんだよ。

context_sentences.en: That model used to be a designer, right?
context_sentences.ja: あのモデルさんって、元々はデザイナーだったんでしょ？

context_sentences.en: This club hasn’t been very popular from the beginning.
context_sentences.ja: 元々、このクラブはあんまりポピュラーじゃないからね。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Your <kanji>origin</kanji> partner is a partner you had originally, but don't have anymore. In other words, this is your <vocabulary>ex-partner</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>former partner</vocabulary>.

Like in English, this word is fairly formal, and it covers any kind of ex-partner, including business and romantic partners.
data.reading_mnemonic: This uses the kun'yomi of <ja>元</ja> and then it's just kana, so you should know how to read this!

context_sentences.en: I got a text from my ex-partner.
context_sentences.ja: 元パートナーからテキストがきた。

context_sentences.en: Oh, it's the same as my ex-partner's necklace.
context_sentences.ja: あ、それ、元パートナーのネックレスといっしょだ。

context_sentences.en: This is a video of me skiing with my ex-partner at Mt. Fuji.
context_sentences.ja: これは、ふじ山で元パートナーとスキーをしたときのビデオだよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Things that make your <kanji>heart</kanji> <kanji>strong</kanji> are <vocabulary>reassuring</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>heartening</vocabulary> to hear. You can practically feel your heart becoming stronger in your chest.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the words <ja>心</ja> and <ja>強い</ja>, so you should be able to read this on your own. Just note that <ja>つよい</ja> gets rendaku'd to <ja>づよい</ja>!

context_sentences.en: This is heartening data!
context_sentences.ja: これは心強いデータですね！

context_sentences.en: Hayashi-san will be a very reassuring partner for you.
context_sentences.ja: 林さんはとても心強いパートナーになるよ。

context_sentences.en: There is nothing more reassuring than having a professional tell me what to do.
context_sentences.ja: プロが教えてくれるなんて、これほど心強いことはないです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've already learned <ja>石</ja>, which means <kanji>stone</kanji>. Add a <ja>ころ</ja> to that, and it becomes a <vocabulary>small stone</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>pebble</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This uses the kun'yomi of <ja>石</ja>, which you've already learned, and adds a bit of hiragana, so you should be able to read this!

context_sentences.en: I'm collecting small stones to paint.
context_sentences.ja: ペイントするための石ころをひろっているんです。

context_sentences.en: Throw this stone at that ninja!
context_sentences.ja: この石ころを、あのニンジャになげるんだ！

context_sentences.en: There are a lot of pebbles on this beach.
context_sentences.ja: このビーチ、石ころがたくさんあるね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: What <kanji>season</kanji>s should you keep an <kanji>eye</kanji> on? The seasons that are <vocabulary>turning point</vocabulary>s in your life. Keep an eye on those seasons, because you don't want to miss the <vocabulary>critical juncture</vocabulary>s and <vocabulary>milestone</vocabulary>s.
data.reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi of both kanji. You haven't learned that yet for <ja>節</ja>, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

The real <vocabulary>turning point</vocabulary> in your life was when you got yourself a <reading>few she</reading>ep (<ja>ふし</ja>). Owning a few sheep was a true <vocabulary>milestone</vocabulary> for you. Now you have all the wool sweaters and cheese you could ever want!

context_sentences.en: The coming-of-age ceremony is an important milestone in one's life.
context_sentences.ja: 成人式は、大切な人生の節目です。

context_sentences.en: Then that year, something happened that would become a major turning point in my life.
context_sentences.ja: そしてその年、人生の大きな節目になる出来事が起こったんです。

context_sentences.en: In hindsight, I guess that was a critical juncture.
context_sentences.ja: 今から思うと、あれが一つの節目だったんだろうね。
